Luisa is requesting a new loan to boost her husband’s business. The loan funds will be invested in the acquistion of ingredients to keep producing the sweets and candies. This way, Luisa and her husband will be able to improve their family’s standard of living.

loans.use: The funds will be invested in raw materials to produce sweets and candies for a pastry shop.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey P., 41, works selling palm juice in her village. On average, she earns around $7 a day of income. Her husband supplements the household income by working collecting palm juice. After collecting, he hands in the palm juice to his wife for selling. They have three children, two of whom work in the garment sector with salaries of $80 each a month, and one who is a student.

To install (repair) their leaking roof, which is very difficult in the raining season, they are now requesting a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: She will use this loan to fix the leaking roof.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong V., 26, works selling small round tables and chairs (all the tables and chairs are made from cement) and makes around $8 a day of income. Her husband is a government clerk in the village. Normally, he earns an average of about $2 a day. They have one little child.

This couple needs money to purchase cement and paint to produce chairs and tables.

loans.use: They will use this loan to purchase cement and paint to produce chairs and tables.

loans.name: Sout

texts.en:
Mrs. Sout C., 37, works selling groceries at her house, earning around $13 a day in revenue. Her husband supports the family income as a mechanic (motorbike) and makes about $8 a day of income. They have four children, three of whom are students and one who stays at home.

To expand the business, this couple is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more grocery products and mechanic tools. (Her husband and the youngest daughter are pictured becuase Mrs. Sout C. was not available).

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products and mechanic tools.

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noun S., 37, is a widow with three children who works selling groceries at home earning around $3 a day of profit. Two of her children work as garment workers with salaries of $40 each a month. Her other child is a student.

She needs a loan from Kiva to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Koy

texts.en:
Mrs. Koy S., 62, is an elderly mother with two children who works as a farmer growing rice and selling groceries at home. Normally, she earns around $3 a day of income. Her husband stays at home. Of her children, one works at a company with a salary of $150 a month, and the other one is a construction worker, making about $70 a month.

To decrease expenses, she aims to use this loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. With the rest of money, she will raise pigs to make an additional income. (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Koy S. was not available)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and raise pigs.

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Mrs. Tom R., 39, is a widow and works as a teacher in the village. Moreover, after her teaching job, she always makes Khmer noodle and sells it in the market. On average, she makes around $6 a day including her teaching salary. She has two children, both of whom are students.

She wants a loan from Kiva to renovate her house as, during the rainy season, she has difficulty with a leaking roof. The leaking roof currently affects her business because she makes Khmer noodle in her house.

loans.use: This loan will be used to fix a leaking roof.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea S., 30, is a mother of one child and, together with her husband, works selling groceries in a busy market. They earn around $5 a day of profit. Her child is a student.

She will use this loan money to buy cashew nuts in stock and resell for profit to make extra income. This will give her family savings for the future and provide a good condition of living.

loans.use: To buy cashew nuts in stock.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim T., 45, is a widow with four children who stays at home to looking after and cook for the children. One of her children is married and lives away from home. Two others are garment workers in Phnom Penh city with a salary $60 each a month. Her other child is a student.

To earn extra income, she needs a loan from Kiva to purchase cashew nuts in stock to resell for profit. Selling cashew nuts is a lucrative business.

loans.use: To purchase cashew nuts in stock.

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khan Y., 54, is a widow with one child. She works selling second hand clothes in a market and makes around $3 a day of profit. Her daughter, Ms. Oun Sreymom, 18, is a singer in a restaurant. On average, she earns $5 in daily wages.

Mrs. Khan Y. needs to add to her clothes inventory to meet her customers' demands.

loans.use: To add to her clothes inventory to meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Chai

texts.en:
Mrs. Chai E. E., 36, works selling grocery products at home and makes an average of around $5 a day of income. Her husband supplements the household by working as a police officer with a salary of $60 a month. ThE. have 3 children, all of whom are students.

She wants to purchase groceries in bulk to save monE., as well as to meet her customers' demands.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk to save money.

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
I have lived all of my life in a small city called Chichawatni in Pakistan. I am a widow and a mother of two kids. I raise goats to supplement my work as a day laborer. When these goats reach a reasonable age I sell them at a decent price. I want to buy a few additional goats for my business.

There are four other women in my loan group: Nazira B., who is borrowing for her grocery store; Walan B., who will invest her share of the loan to buy a machine for their business; Manzoora B., who embroiders clothes; and Parween A., who wants to buy a donkey cart. These women are very cooperative and will repay your loan on time in a responsible manner.

loans.use: Buy a few goats

loans.name: Manh

texts.en: Mr. Manh M. is a 43-year-old farmer and fish seller in Daun La Or Village, Kampong Thom Province. He earns an average of $3 per day. His wife, Mrs. Van Vet, is 36 years old and also farms and sells fish, earning about $2 per day. M. has four children, two of whom work in a garment factory and provide their family about $2 per day. Mr. M. is now requesting a $1,200 loan to buy a motorcycle for his business transportation. With his fish-selling business, he can increase his income so he can support his children’s studies and help reduce his family’s expenses. M. thanks Kiva for their support and promises prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for his business transportation

loans.name: Munnaza's Group

texts.en:
I am Munnaza A., and I am the loan group leader. I live with my family in a four room brick house in the small town of Chichawatni in Pakistan. I have two girls and one boy, and they are studying in grades five, three and two. My husband lives abroad and his brother lives with me. I am borrowing for my brother-in-law who runs a milk shop.

There are a few other women who are also in need of loans. These women are: Ramzan Z., whose husband sells fruits and vegetables on commission; Nazira G., who wants to buy a dairy cow; Sughran Z., who will invest her share of the loan in her family’s furniture business; and Nazira A. D., who needs to buy a donkey cart. I want to help these women so that they can fight against poverty and secure good futures for their families.

loans.use: Expand milk sales

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
My name is Zarina M., and I am married and a mother of two boys. My elder son is five years old and attends kindergarten, while the younger son is four years old also attends kindergarten. My husband is a carpenter and he buys and sells wood in a nearby big city.

I would like to share this loan with a few other women who have joined me in this loan group, and they are: Zarina M., who is borrowing for her wholesale business; Rani A. S., who will use the loan to improve their fruit business; Balqees I., who will also improve her business; and Riffat B., who wants to buy wood. All of these women dream of a comfortable, and sound economic, life.

loans.use: Expand wood business

loans.name: Tei

texts.en: Mr. Tei N., 55, is a farmer and fisherman in the Kork Snay Village, Kampong Thom Province. N. earns up to $3 per day. His wife, Mrs. Yoem Roem, is a 53-year-old farmer and grows crops, including watermelons, earning about $5 per day. They have seven children, one married and the others single. N. requests a loan of $1,100 to buy fishing tools and to plant dry season rice. He thanks Kiva for their support and promises prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To buy fishing tools and to plant dry season rice

loans.name: Nazhat's Group

texts.en:
I am Nazhat S., and I come from a small city called Chichawatni in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of two daughters. I live in a one room brick and mud house, and my husband and I sell milk from our house. We have a few cows, but need to buy an additional cow.

Chichawatni is a small town and there not many employment opportunities so many people have small self-owned businesses to make a living. I also have a few other women in my loan group, and they are in need of loans to expand and improve their businesses. These women are: Nazia N., who will use the loan to expand their wood business; Bushra B., who will increase their livestock trading; Koser P., who wants to buy a donkey cart; and Rukhsana B., who runs a general store.

loans.use: Buy an additional cow

loans.name: Saom

texts.en:
Mrs. Saom Y., 50, is a widow with eight children. She works making Khmer food (a roll made of hashed meat - usually pork) wrapped and cooked in banana leaves. Normally, people like eating this with wine or beer. On average, she earns around $2.50 a day in profit. One of her children is employed as a hotel security guard with a salary $50 a month, and helps her mother make the food.

The loan from Kiva will be used to purchase rice, banana leaves and generator gas. She wants to expand the business to gain more profits. (Mrs. Saom Y. is pictured with her daughter.)

loans.use: To purchase rice, banana leaves and generator gas.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Mrs. Pen Y., 34, works purchasing a variety of vegetables and fruits from the farmland and reselling in the market. Typically, she earns around $2 a day. Her husband, Mr. Seoun Sor, 36, is a car mechanic in the village and makes about $3 a day. This couple has two children and both of them are students.

She wants to use this loan to purchase a motorbike to transfer the fruits and vegetables from the farmland to the market. This will reduce daily expense, as currently, she pays a lot to the motor-taxi driver to transport her vegetables to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Cheok

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheok S., 41, is a widow with one child, and works making Khmer food (a roll made of hashed meat - usually pork) wrapped and cooked in banana leaves. On average, she makes about $3 a day.

The loan from Kiva will be used to purchase rice and banana leaves. She hopes the business will give her family more income. (Mrs. Cheok S. is pictured with her daughter)

loans.use: To purchase rice and banana leaves.

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Eoun A., 23, owns a plot of farmland growing a variety of vegetables, and makes an average of around $3 a day in profit. Her husband works selling charcoal. He transfers charcoal by cA. and sells door to door in the village making around $4 a day in profit. They have one child and he is too young to attend school yet.

This loan will be used to purchase more firewood to turn into charcoal. They also plan to send their child to university in the future. (Mrs. Eoun A. is pictured with her husband and Credit Officer)

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to turn into charcoal.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. Mao M., 51, is the head of his family. To support the family income, he works as a motor-taxi driver. He earns approximately $3 a day of profit. His wife, Mrs.Kaot Njem, 46, is a company staff member with a salary of $150 a month. They have six children, two of whom are married and live away from home and others who stay at home and do not earn an income.

To earn an additional income, Mrs. Kaot Njem is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her son to run a business (motor-taxi driver). If she has enough money in the future, she will buy a market stand for her daughters to sell groceries. (Mrs. Kaot Njem is pictured with her youngest son)

loans.use: To purchase a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en:
Tinh and her husband Dung have a small grocery store at their home. They sell a wide variety of items in their grocery store, including vegetables, candy, and household tools. Much of their income goes towards raising their young three year old daughter. Last time they had received $75 from Kiva for their business and earned between 300,000 - 450,000 VND per month. They paid all their loan back and now they would like to continue their partnership with Kiva by requesting to borrow 1,200,000 VND.


.

loans.use: To increase grocery store stock

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
Mrs. Yi S., 50, owns a plot of farmland growing corn. Typically, she earns $2 a day of profit. Her husband is a tailor, making, on average, around $2 a day of profit.

Mrs. Yi S. has 6 children. One son works as a driver and one daughter is employed by a garment factory. The rest of the children are students.

She will use this loan to purchase a good seed (corn) to grow for next year to gain more output. (Mrs. Yi S. is pictured with a Credit Officer.)

loans.use: To purchase a good seed (corn).

loans.name: Abdurahimova

texts.ru:
N. Abdurahimova is 35. She is a good seamstress, but now she is on a maternity leave. N. Abdurahimova has 5 children with her youngest being only 2 years old. N. earns an income by raising a variety of farm animals. She now has 20 goats and 8 rams. Now, N. Abdurahimova asks for this loan to purchase 2 cows. N.’s oldest son helps her to run the farm. N.’s husband is in Russia working as a seasonal laborer.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдурахимова Насиба женщина в возросте 35 лет имеет средне- техническое образование.Хорошая портниха на дому, но сейчас она сидит в дикретном отпуске.Она имеет 5 детей , младшему ребенку 2 годика.В свободное время занимается откормом скота.Сейчас имеет 20 коз и 8 баранов .Но сейчас она хочет в кредит купить две коровы,одну из них буренку чтоб иметь свое молоко. Ей помогает старший сын по уходу за скотом .Муж на заработках в Российской Федерации.

loans.use: To purchase 2 cows

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40687

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence M.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase another electric sewing machine. Florence is 49 years old and is married with a husband who is a farmer for work. She has 3 children ranging from ages 19 to 24 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 180000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children and construct a house. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to buy more stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Edith W., Hamidah N., Monica K., and Ruth K.. Edith W. has a business running a kiosk and wants to add more stock. Hamidah N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to boost business. Monica K. operates a business selling clothes and wants to increase her inventory. Ruth K. is currently in the business of running a kiosk and is requesting a loan to put up another kiosk.

loans.use: To add working capital to tailoring business

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Suzan T.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy an over-locking machine for tailoring. Suzan is 27 years old and is married with a husband who is a welder for work. She has 3 children ranging from age 2 months to 6 years old, and two children go to school. Each week, Suzan makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide basic needs to her children. Suzan has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to buy a sewing machine and the loan was paid back on time.

Suzan is joined in her small group by Mariam K., Sarah M. and Aisha N.. Mariam K. has a business running a stationery shop and wants to buy a computer. Sarah M. is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to expand and become a supplier. Aisha N. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase more utensils.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring equipment

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Madinah N.. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to add more stock. Madinah is 33 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 8 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Madinah makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save. Madinah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Madinah is joined in her small group by Ruth B., Robinah K., Deziranta N., and Lakele N.. Ruth B. has a business selling charcoal and wants to open a business in another location. Robinah K. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to add more stock. Deziranta N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to add more equipment. Lakele N. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase a bicycle to transport the charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ecery J.. She is currently in the business of building and is requesting a loan to buy building machinery. Ecery is 31 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver for work. She has 1 school going daughter aged 12. Each week, Ecery makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her personal needs and save the rest. Ecery has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to buy a commercial motorcycle and the loan was paid back on time.

Ecery is joined in her small group by Jesca K., Betty B. and Beat N.. Jesca K. has a business running a retail shop and grocery store and wants to purchase a fridge and add more stock. Betty B. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Beat N. operates a retail shop business and wants to buy more crates of sodas.

loans.use: To add to building business

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(V) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Zaina K.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase more poultry birds. Zaina is 42 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 7 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Zaina makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet her basic needs like food and shelter. Zaina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Zaina is joined in her small group by Harriet A., Rehema A. and Zaina M.. Harriet A. has a business milling maize and wants to stock more maize. Rehema A. is currently operating a business selling raw food and wants a loan to add capital. Zaina M. operates a poultry farming business and sells clothes and wants to construct a poultry house.

loans.use: To boost and expand poultry business

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village B(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Grace B.. She is currently in the business of selling dairy products and is requesting a loan to purchase a freezer and more milk cans. Grace is 49 years old and is married with a husband who is a builder for work. She has 6 children ranging from ages 13 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Grace makes approximately UGX 150000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business and save the rest. Grace has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Grace is joined in her small group by Edith N., Aidah A. and Milly B.. Edith N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to add more furniture. Aidah A. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes. Milly B. operates a tailoring business and wants to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: To increase inventory in milk business

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mirabu N.. She is currently in the business of running a kiosk and is requesting a loan to add more stock and buy a weighing scale. Mirabu is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a coffee trader for work. She has 3 children ranging from ages 11 to 17 and her children go to school. Each week, Mirabu makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re- invest in her business. Mirabu has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mirabu is joined in her small group by Happy Tibinwera and Jane K.. Happy Tibinwera has a business in craft sales and wants to increase her capital stock. Jane K. is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To increase stock in kiosk shop

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hamida K.. She is currently in the business of selling new shoes and is requesting a loan to purchase more shoes. Hamida is 25 years old and is single. Each week, Hamida makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Hamida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Hamida is joined in her small group by Lukia B. and Mutesi M.. Lukia B. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase more utensils. Mutesi M. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to add more stock.

loans.use: To purchase more used shoes in large quantities

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Monica N.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes. Monica is 32 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from ages 2 to 15, and most of her children go to school. Each week, Monica makes approximately UGX 120000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her personal needs and save the rest. Monica has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add stock to the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Monica is joined in her small group by Margret K. and Justine N.. Margret K. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase the amount of commodities in her shop. Justine N. is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to expand to wholesale.

loans.use: To add more working capital to clothing business

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ruth N.. She is currently in the business of selling used shoes and is requesting a loan to enlarge her business buy adding more stock. Ruth is 37 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 3 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Ruth makes approximately UGX 140000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet personal needs. Ruth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to use in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Ruth is joined in her small group by Jalia N. and Beth K.. Jalia N. has a business selling second hand shoes and wants to add capital stock. Beth K. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to expand to wholesale selling.

loans.use: To boost and expand shoe business to increase profits

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Harriet S.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy a weighing scale. Harriet is 35 years old and is married with a husband who is a commercial motorcyclist for work. She has 4 children ranging from ages 3 to 12 and most of her children go to school. Each week, Harriet makes approximately UGX 75000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Betty B.. Betty B. has a business selling charcoal and wants to expand and become a supplier.

loans.use: To purchase more shop items

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Nancy Z.. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase in bulk. Nancy is 36 years old and is married. Her husband has a hardware shop. She has 5 children ranging from ages 4 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Nancy makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Nancy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her clothing business and the loan was paid back on time.

Nancy is joined in her small group by Mariam N. and Winnie A.. Mariam N. has a business selling water and sugarcane and wants to add more stock and purchase a water tank. Winnie A. is currently operating a public pay phone business and selling clothes and wants a loan to buy another phone and more clothes.

loans.use: To increase clothing purchases

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(V) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Becca N.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Becca is 25 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from ages 7 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Becca makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Becca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy more charcoal and the loan was paid back on time.

Becca is joined in her small group by Lucy T. and Fauzia N.. Lucy T. has a business running a kiosk and wants to add more stock. Fauzia N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes in bulk.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business and make more profits

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(Vi) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Juliet M.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge. Juliet is 30 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from ages 5 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Juliet makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Juliet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to buy furniture and the loan was paid back on time.

Juliet is joined in her small group by Annet A.. Annet A. has a business running a kiosk and wants to add more stock.

loans.use: To add more equipment to restaurant in order to offer better services

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village C(Vii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty W.. She is currently in the business of rearing poultry and is requesting a loan to buy more broiler chicks. Betty is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver for work. She has 5 children ranging from ages 9 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 140000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Jesca K., Kirabo M., Lukia N., and Lukia B.. Jesca K. has a business selling charcoal and wants to purchase in bulk. Kirabo M. is currently operating a business milling and selling maize and wants a loan to buy more maize. Lukia N. operates a livestock farming business and wants to purchase animal feed. Lukia B. is currently in the business of running a grocery shop and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To add working capital to poultry business

loans.name: Meng

texts.en:
Mrs. Meng K., 55, is a mother of ten children. She works growing a variety of vegetables and earns around $4 a day of income. Her husband is a teacher in the village with a salary of $45 a month. Three of her children are married and live away from home. One daughter works in a garment factory and another one sells groceries.

Mrs. Meng K. wants to use a loan from Kiva to purchase fertilizers and petroleum and more grocery inventory for her daughter. (Mrs. Meng K., wearing the black shirt, is pictured with her neighbor and her husband sitting behind.)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and petroleum and more grocery inventory for her daughter.

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village A(Vi) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Nulu L.. She is currently in the business of selling shoes and is requesting a loan to purchase shoes in large quantities. Nulu is 36 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier for work. She has 6 children ranging from age 3 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Nulu makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Nulu has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to buy more shoes and the loan was paid back on time.

Nulu is joined in her small group by Esther W. and Hadija N.. Esther W. operates a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to boost business. Hadija Nabawabuka is currently operating a business in tailoring and selling clothes and intends to buy more fabric and add to her stock with the loan.

loans.use: To increase inventory in shoe business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng ChanD., 31, stays at home looking after her young child and cooking food for her family. In addition to the house work, she also breeds pigs. On average, she earns less than $1 a day. Her husband is a taxi-driver between Kampong Cham and Phnom Penh. He earns $5 of profit every day.

She needs this loan so that she can raise more pigs and increase her earnings.

loans.use: To raise more pigs

loans.name: Kamuli Rd Village B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Peace B.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase her purchases. Peace is 26 years old and is married with a husband who is an accountant for work. She has a daughter aged 2. Each week, Peace makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save and re-invest the rest in her business. Peace has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Peace is joined in her small group by Harriet N., Mirabu K., and Jane W.. Harriet N. has a business selling used clothes and wants to boost business. Mirabu K. is currently operating a business selling used clothes and wants a loan to rent permanent business premises. Jane W. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Mrs. Sen C., 30, is the mother of one child. She stays at home looking after her child and cooking food for her family. Her husband works growing a variety of vegetables on a plot of farmland; he makes about $1.50 a day of profit.

With this loan, they will purchase fertilizers to put on their corps to gain more profits.

(Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Sanobarhon

texts.ru:
Sanobarhon A.lives in the village of Bohtar. She is 54, married, and has 2 children. Sanobarhon A.is a house wife and she maintains a small cattle farm. Sanobarhon A.plans to use this loan to purchase a milk cow to sell milk and thus improve her family’s financial standing. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдукодирова Санобархон проживает в районе Бохтар. Возраст 54 года. Замужем , имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Домохозяйка. имеет небольшое хозяйство, где имеются бычки. Хочет приобрести дойную корову ,для того чтобы получаемое молоко продавать и улучшить финансовое положение в семье.Кроме того у населения всегда пользуется спросом молочная продукция , поэтому продавать молоко всегда выгодно. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Zumratbi

texts.ru:
Zumratbi N. lives in the village of Rudaki. She is 52, married and has 6 children. Zumratbi N. sells shoes at the “Korvon” market in Dushanbe. She buys the shoes wholesale from Chinese suppliers and then retails them at the market. This business is the main source of income for Zumratbi N.’s family. Zumratbi N. asks for this loan to increase the volume of goods sold and, consequently, her profits. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Ниедова Зумратби проживает в районе Рудаки.Возраст 52 года. Замужем , имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей . продает обувь на рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе.Заказывает товар в Китай Оптовым поставщикам , а затем продает в розницу. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода ее семьи, поэтому ей необходимо развивать свой бизнес путем увеличения товарооборота.Это поможет клиентке увеличить ассортимент и соответственно прибыльность бизнеса.Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase inventory and variety of goods sold

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mehrinisso

texts.ru:
Mehrinisso H. lives in Khuroson, Tajikistan. She is 34, married, and has 1 child. Mehrinisso H. has a college degree in teaching. She works as a school teacher at the local secondary school number 24. In addition, Mehrinisso H. would like to purchase a milk cow, so that she can sell milk to earn some extra money for her family. She needs this loan to finance the purchase. Mehrinisso H. plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хасанова Мехриниссо Джураевна проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст 34 года. Замужем , имеет 1 ребенка.Образование высшее. По профессии учитель средней школы. Работает учителем в средней школе № 24 района Хуросон.Кроме того хочет приобрести дойную корову ,для тогочтобы получаемое молоко продавать и получать дополнительный доход.Это поможет улучшить финансовое положение семьи.Кроме того у населения всегда пользуется спросом молочная продукция , поэтому продавать молоковсегда выгодно. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Dung

texts.en:
Dung, 65 years old, sells sweet tofu soup at a street stall in Tanh Linh. Her husband, Hai, is 73 years old. As her husband is no longer working, the tofu stand is their only source of income. Before receiving a loan from Mekong Plus, Dung was only able sell her sweet tofu soup in the mornings due to a limited amount of ingredients. With the money she had earned, she could only buy rice to eat.

She has borrowed twice from Mekong Plus and once from Kiva before. Now, Dung is able to sell all day and she earns between 10-15,000 VND ($0.62-0.94) per day. She wishes to partner with Mekong Plus and Kiva once again to help her business grow.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Sokkheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokkheng S. and her husband, Orn Hun, have been married for ten years. They have three children; one son and two daughters. One of her daughters is in school and the other two children are still young and stay at home. The family lives along the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sokkheng has been a silk weaver for thirteen years. It’s a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village. Her husband has been a construction worker for eight years.

Mrs. Sokkheng is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: For purchasing silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Sey

texts.en:
Mrs. Sey P., 46, is married with four children. She works as a weaver and makes $2 a day of profit. Her husband has a business installing a music system whenever there is a celebration, party, or wedding in the village. On average, he earns around $4 a day of profit.

Three of their children are garment workers and the other is a student.

They will use this loan to renovate their house.

loans.use: They will use ths loan to renovate their house

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa H. and her husband have been married for five years. They have one little daughter. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Channa has been selling bananas and flowers for many years. She buys jasmine flowers and bananas from a farmer in her village for resale at market in Phnom Penh. Her husband grows bananas, cucumbers and vegetables on a farm near their house. He sells his products to the middle man in the village.

Mrs. Channa is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $800 to purchase longans (a lychee-type fruit) on contract and to buy a motorbike to carry flowers and bananas to sell in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase longans and a motorbike

loans.name: Chon

texts.en:
Mrs. Chon N., 46, is a widow with four children. She works as weaver and earns around $2 a day.

One of her children works in a restaurant earning a salary $60 a month and another is employed by a garment factory and earns around $2.50 per day. Her other two children work growing vegetables.

With this loan, Mrs. Chon N. will invest in her business and make some repairs to her house.

loans.use: To renovate the house

loans.name: Ashur

texts.ru:
Ashur I. lives in Qurgan-Tube, Tajikistan. He is 49, married, and has three children. Ashur I. is a tractor operator, by occupation, but he also sells spare auto parts. He brings the parts from Dushanbe and sells them at the central market of his town. Ashur I. has been in business for three years. Since auto parts sales is Ashur’s primary income, he asks for a loan to expand his business. He will use the money to increase the variety and the volume of goods he sells. Ashur I. plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Ишмуродов ашур житель города Курга-Тюбе. Возраст 49 лет ,женат имеет троих детей. Образование среднее , по специальности тракторист. Кроме того занимается торговлей запчастей.Завозит товар из города Душанбе и продает у себя в городе.На центральном рынке города крган-тюбе имеет торговую точку по продаже запчастей для тракторов и другой техники. Знимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 3 года. Так как данная деятельность является основным источником дохода его семьи клиенту требуется дополнительное финансирование. Поэтому он запланировал получить кредит. Кроме того увеличив товарооборот , клиент увеличит ассортимент товара, а это поможет населению покупать необходимые вещи не выезжая за приделы города.Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase the volume of goods sold

loans.name: Orn

texts.en:
Mrs. Orn C. and her husband have been married for thirty-seven years. They have eight children; six sons and two daughters. Five of their children are married and live outside the family home; the other three are farming with their parents. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Orn and her husband have been farming for forty-three years. They grow bananas and corns on a farm far from their house. They are in late 50’s but still strong enough to work.

Mrs. Orn is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of $1100 to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides for growing corn and cucumbers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides for growing corn and cucumbers.

loans.name: Ye

texts.en:
Mrs. Ye N. and her husband have been married for twelve years. They have four sons, three of whom study in primary school. The youngest one stays at home. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Ye and her husband have been selling fish for two years. They buy them from fisherman in the village for resale at Chaba Ampov Market in Phnom Penh. Besides selling fish, her husband also runs a motor taxi.

Mrs. Ye is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $1000 to purchase fish for resale and to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale and to repair her house.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim N., 43, is the mother of three children and works as a farmer growing rice; she earns $3 a day. Her husband fishes for a living. After catching fish, he sells his catch in the market to earn approximately $5 a day of revenue.

One of her children works in a factory, the other two are students.

She will use this loan to purchase good rice seeds and fertilizers. She will use the remaining money to buy another plot of farmland to grow more rice.

loans.use: To purchase good rice seeds, fertilizers and a plot of farmland

loans.name: Da

texts.en:
Mrs. Da S. and her husband, Thy Hel, have been married for three years. They have no children. The family lives along the Mekong River, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Mrs. Da has been a silk weaver for twenty-three years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village. Her husband has been a driver for a company for six years.

She is requesting a loan for the fifth time in the amount $400 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: For purchasing silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Ngan

texts.en:
Ngan, 49 years old, sells sweet rice dishes on the back of her bicycle. As a single mother, she raises a 15-year-old boy and 10-year-old girl, on her own. Ngan usually only sells her dish in the morning from 5 am to 8 am. Afterwards, she works as a day laborer. However, the work is very difficult and dangerous. She hopes to improve her street food business so that she will not have to work as a day laborer.

In the past, Nhung has received loans from Mekong Plus and Kiva which she has successfully repaid on time. She has been able to earn 15-20,000 VND ($0.94-1.25) per day. With her increased earnings, she bought a bicycle for her children to ride to school. She hopes to partner with Mekong Plus and Kiva again.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Sopois

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopois N., 27, and her husband, Daro Man, married in 2004. They have two little children; one son and one daughter. The family lives on Koh Dach Island on the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sopois is in the business of weaving silk. She learned weaving from her neighbor and started silk production in 1999. She sells her finished products in her village.

Mrs. Sopois is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $500 to purchase silk material for weaving and for repairing her house.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and to repairing her house

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Mrs. Nov H., 43, is the mother of three children and works with her husband growing rice on a plot of farmland. On average, they earn around $2 a day.

Two of their children are married and live away from home. Their other daughter is a garment worker earning a salary of $80 a month.

This loan will be used to purchase a grinding mill.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill

loans.name: Hammat

texts.en:
Mr. Hammat Y. and his wife, Srifas Mat, have been married for nine years. They have four daughters, one of whom is in school and other three are still young and stay at home. Their house is along the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Hammat and his wife have been fishing since they were young. They fish the from Mekong River and then sell the fish at the village market.

Mr. Hammat is requesting a loan for the second time in the amount of $300 to purchase fishing material for his business.

loans.use: For purchasing fishing materials

loans.name: Nhung

texts.en: Nhung, 36 years old, runs a small shop in the front of her house where she sells mainly school supplies and snacks. As a single mother, Nhung raises her 10-year-old son, Luu Minh Hoang, on her own. Her track record has proven both reliable and trustworthy as she has successfully repaid a loan from Mekong Plus in the past. She would like a loan from KIVA in order to increase her store's stock. She is able to earn between 10-15,000 VND ($0.62-0.94) per day. With the money she earns, she sends her son to school.

loans.use: To increase her shop's stock

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Mrs. Kun A., 53, is a widow. She stays at home doing the house work while her two grown children go to work. Her son Mr. Kun Pong, 30, is a factory manager in Phnom Penh earning a salary $150 a month. Her daughter is a garment worker with a salary of $100 a month.

Mrs. Kun A. will use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her son. He currently has to commute to work on a motor-taxi, which costs him a lot. This motorbike will allow him save in the future.

(Mrs. Kun A. is pictured with her son.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Sulfa

texts.en:
Mr. Sulfa L. and his wife, Khortichas Tres, have been married for twelve years. They have five children; four sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the other two are still young and stay at home. The house is along the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Sulfa has been selling goats since late last year. He buys goats from nearby provinces and sells them in Phnom Penh. He used to do this business two years ago. Now, he is starting it again, because the goats now command a good price. His wife stays at home takes care of their children.

Mr. Sulfa is requesting a loan for the second time in the amount of US$800 to purchase goats for resale.

loans.use: To purchase goats for resale

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Mr. Kan S. and his wife, Rum Mol, have been married since 2002. They have three sons. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Kan has been fishing for six years. He fishes in the lake near his village and then sells the fish at Prek Pnao Market. His wife has been selling vegetables for twenty years. She buys them from farmers in the village for resale at Prek Pnao Market.

Mr. Kan is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $700 to purchase a boat motor and fishing net for his fishing business.

loans.use: For purchasing a boat motor and fishing net

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha T. (pictured with her first son) and her husband have five children; two sons and three daughters. All of their children are working. The first son has been in construction for four years and two of her daughters weave silk at home. The family lives in Mekong River’s Island, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chantha started weaving silk when she was young. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in her village. Her husband, Van Vin, is a chef for wedding ceremonies.

Mrs. Chantha is requesting a loan for the second time in the amount of $700 to purchase construction material for her first son.

loans.use: To purchase construction material for her son

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Mrs. Sean Y., 34, works selling chicken in a busy market, making on average around $3.50 of profit per day. Her husband Mr. Mot Mak, 34, is a musician in the village; on average, he earns about $2 a day of profit. All four of their children are students.

This loan will be used to purchase more chicken to sell in the market to meet customer demand.

(Mrs. Sean Y. is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase more chicken to sell

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Sean Yi and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Veong

texts.en:
Mrs. Veong H., 34, has seven children and works with her husband selling chicken in a busy market. They earn about $8 of profit per day.

Two of their children are married and live away from home. Two others work in a garment factory and earn a salary of $100 each a month.

Mrs. Veong H. will use this loan to purchase more chicken to meet customer demand.

(Husband is pictured because Mrs. Veong H. is not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more chicken to sell

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Mrs. Hem C., 36, is the mother of three children and works as a tailor. She earns around $1 a day of profit. Her husband owns a plot of farmland growing rice and makes around $1 a day of profit as well. All three of their children are students.

She has requested this loan so that she can begin to raise pigs and earn extra income.

loans.use: To purcahse and raise pigs

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.ru:
Jamshed G. lives in Rudaki. He is 26, married, and has 3 children. Jamshed G. works as a policeman in Rudaki. As a supplemental source of income, he also has a cattle farm. Jamshed G. buys the animals at a local market, raises and profitably resells them after 40-45 days. He has been in this business for 3 years. Jamshed G. will use this loan to purchase young bulls. He plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Ганиев Джамшед проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст 26 лет . Женат, имеет 3 детей . Образование средне-специальное. По профессии милиционер, работает в ОВД района Рудаки. Занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно-рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Покупает товар на рынке района, откармливает около 40-45 дней , а затем перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 3 года. Этот бизнес является дополнительным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом. Клиент хочет получить кредит для того чтобы закупить молодых бычков. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Cheoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheoun I., 28, is the mother of two children and works as a garment worker, making about $3 a day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and can earn as much as $3 a day of profit.

The couple has requested this loan to replace their old motorbike, which is unreliable and uses lots of gas.

(Mrs. Cheoun I., pictured with her husband and one of her children.)

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike

loans.name: Yormuhammad

texts.ru:
Yormuhammad Nuralievich Z. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 33 years old, married and has five children. He has a college education and is an economist by profession. He is also in the animal husbandry and agriculture business and breeds cattle for resale for meat. He buys the cattle on the market, feeds it for 40-45 days and then resells for a more profitable price and has been doing this for the past ten years. This business is the secondary source of income for his family. Additionally, the development of this type of business also allows to supply the markets with meat. Yormuhammad wants to use the loan to buy younger calves. He plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Зохиров Ермухаммад Нуралиевич проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст 33 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей . Образование высшее . По профессии экономист. Занимается земледелием и животноводством. Разводит крупно-рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Покупает товар на рынке района, откармливает около 40-45 дней , а затем перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 10 лет. Этот бизнес является дополнительным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом. Клиент хочет получить кредит для того чтобы закупить молодых бычков. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy calves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao S., 45, is married with four children. She owns a plot of farmland and earns an average of $2 a day growing rice. Her husband works making pig-traps from rattan and earns around $2 a day as well.

One of their daughters is employed by a garment factory and earns a salary $50 a month. Their other children are students.

This couple has requested a loan to begin raising pigs, which will earn them extra income.

loans.use: Purchase pigs to breed

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. is a 36-year-old mother of 5 children. She is taking out a second loan from Sinapi Aba Trust. With the proceeds of her first loan, she was able to expand her stock to include selling kente. Kente is a traditional Ashanti cloth that is hand woven and is considered a pride to wear and sell. With this second loan, Esther wants to continue expanding her operations and has become an enthusiastic supporter of Sinapi. She now has given part of her apartment for group meetings with Sinapi.

Due to her living conditions, 3 of her 5 children are currently with her mother. She hopes that this loan will someday afford her the opportunity to have her 3 other children live with her as well. She also expressed a dream to have all of her children attend university someday.

Esther is standing on the right, proudly displaying some of her kente. On the left is Esther's loan officer, Dorothy.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of products

loans.name: Suhrob

texts.ru:
Suhrob Djurabekovich K. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 28 years old, married and has two children. He has secondary education and is in the agriculture and animal husbandry business. He breeds cattle for resale for meat. He buys cattle on the market, feeds it for about 40-45 days and then resells for a more profitable price and has been doing this for the past five years. This business is the secondary source of income for his family. Additionally, the development of this type of business also allows to supply the markets with meat. Suhrob wants to use the loan to buy younger calves. He plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Курбонов Сухроб Джурабекович проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст28 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей . Образование среднее. Занимается земледелием и животноводством. Разводит крупно-рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Покупает товар на рынке района, откармливает около 40-45 дней , а затем перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 5 лет. Этот бизнес является дополнительным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом. Клиент хочет получить кредит для того чтобы закупить молодых бычков. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy calves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hon

texts.en:
Mrs. Hon V., 52, is the mother of five children and works with her husband growing rice on their plot of farmland. They earn about $3 a day.

Two of their daughters are garment workers in Phnom Penh, each earning $100 per month. One of their sons is a security guard earning a salary $50 a month. Their other children live at home and work on the farm.

This couple will use their loan to renovate their house as their current house is too old. (Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To renovate their house

loans.name: Mey

texts.en: Mrs. Mey S. and her husband work together catching fish which they then sell to a market. They earn around $3 a day of profit. They will use this loan to purchase a motorbike to transfer their fish to the market.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike to transport their catch

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mrs. Mon S. works selling a variety of fruits in a busy market; she earns around $2.50 a day of profit. Her husband is a land broker; he generally makes about $3 a day. They have one child who goes to school.

They have requested this loan because they would like to begin raising pigs, a popular and profitable activity in the province.

loans.use: This loan will be used to raise pigs

loans.name: Hay

texts.en:
Mrs. Hay C., 34, works selling a variety of fruits and earns around $5.50 a day. Her husband Mr. Chun Buntheoun, 43, is a construction worker who builds houses; on average, he earns $6 a day. They have four small children.

The loan will be used to purchase new construction tools as well as a motorbike to transfer fruits to and from the market.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools and a motorbike

loans.name: Abdurahimov

texts.ru:
Z. Abdurahimov is a young man of 26 years, married and has one child. His wife is a housewife and he is in the animal husbandry. He loves to breed cattle and currently has one cow and twenty goats. His wife spins yarn from goat fur and makes some profit from it. Z. also works in the construction team during the summer and autumn months. He has turned to MicroInvest for a loan to buy more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдурахимов Зокирджон молодой человек в возросте 26 лет , женат имеет 1 ребенка жена домохозяйка.Сам занимается только уходом и откормом скота.Очень любит домашний скот , на данный момент имеет 1 корову и 20 коз.Жена занимается производством козьей пряжи, с чего тоже имеет доход.Зокирджон также в сезонное время (летом и весной )работает на стройке в бригаде.В Микроинвест обратился чтоб взяв кредит купить еще скот.

loans.use: To buy cattle

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40743

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is an energetic and enterprising mother of 4 children and owns a corner store that sells various household items, including plastic chairs, plastic containers, and ropes.

Her first son is currently attending nursing school, and her second son is eager to attend university. She hopes this loan will allow her to generate more income to support her son's dream of attending university.

She is a member of the trust group called With God. The trust group works under the principle of peer pressure, where each member of the group guarantees for each other in case of default.

Stella stands in front of her store on the right side of her loan officer, Dorothy, and Joshua, the Kiva coordinator for Sinapi.

loans.use: To expand her inventory to raise her income

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Madeleine is married and has been a member of the Lyndiane Catholic Women’s village bank in Ziguinchor for 6 and a half years. She has considerable experience in the sale of forestry products such as palm oil and lemon oil, among others. The income from these sales allows her to help her family. She would like to build her business and is requesting a loan that she promises to repay in one installment within 6 months.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Madeleine, mariée est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Lyndiane à Ziguinchor depuis 6 ans et demie. Elle a une bonne expérience du commerce des produits forestiers: huile de palme, citron, etc. Ces revenus lui permettent d'aider à l'entretien de sa famille.Elle souhaite renforcer son activité et sollicite un prêt qu'elle s'engage de rembourser au bout de 06 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Purchase of palm oil for resale

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly L., 34, is married and has four children. She earns $3 per day as a garment worker. Her husband Mr. Saom Suy, 38, is a wedding chef in the village and normally earns about $2.50 a day. All four of their children are students.

This loan will be used to purchase groceries, plates, and pans as well as renovate their house.

loans.use: To purchase groceries, plates, and pans as well as renovate their house

loans.name: Abdurahimov

texts.ru:
A. Abdurahimov is a man of 26 and is currently divorced. He lives with his elderly mother. His main income comes from his profession and he is a known shepherd in his kishlak (village). By his estimates, he herds aproximately a hundred sheep. About half of them are not owned by him, but he is paid well for taking good care of them. This is why Abduchaboor wants to increase his own cattle stock and turned to Microinvest for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдурахимов Абдучаббор мужчина в возросте 26 лет в данное время разведен .Живет с пожелой матерью.Его доход сотоит из его профессии , в своем кишлаке он знаменитый постух.По его подсчетам он посет где-то одну сотню баранов.Хотя половину из них не его собственность , но за хороший уход ему платят хозяева скота.Поэтому Абдучаббор хочет увеличить свой личный скот,для чего и обратился в Микроинвест.

loans.use: To increase cattle stock

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40747

loans.name: Ratna

texts.en:
Ratna N. is a resident of Tangal, Lalitpur, and lives with her husband and two sons. The Tangal area is a very busy shopping area of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses, especially famous for brass, copper, and bronze pots and utensils in different varieties. Mrs. N. is a shopkeeper in Tangal, and sells pots and utensils. Her two sons are studying in grade 12 and 11 respectively. Mrs. N., along with her husband, Om Bahadur N., opened their shop 6 years ago. They equally contribute their efforts in their shop because they have no other source of income, and their children also help them.

Mrs. N. is asking for her fifth loan to expand her shop by buying items like plates, steel glasses, and hotpots, to meet the increasing demands of customers. They want to strengthen the economic conditions of their family by increasing their income.

loans.use: To buy items for her shop

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is a 48-year-old entrepreneur. She is a widow and lives in Kisumu, Kenya, with her eleven children. She is well-known in her community as an expert in making one of the local favorites, mandazis (fried sweet dough). Her net current income is limited to Kshs 1000 compared to her initial net income of initial Kshs 1500. This is due to the rise in cost of raw materials and local competition. Prisca supplements her current business with her small corner shop where she sells the daily necessities, like bread, flour, cooking oil and soap. She has managed to increase her daily income by 150% and saved a bit of her profits. To increase her stock and to obtain supplies that are in high demand within her community, Prisca has applied for a loan of US $600.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Increase her stock and additional supplies

loans.name: Najat

texts.en:
Najat is a 36-year-old mother with 1 10-year-old son, who is currently in primary school. She sells household items such as plastic chairs and water containers at her corner store.

With her store, she has been able to raise the income of her family. She wants to use this loan to further expand her business and her family income. Her son hopes to be a doctor someday, and Najat would like to start saving to help him achieve his dream.

Najat is a member of the trust group called With God. The trust group is based on peer pressure between members to repay their share of the loan.

Najat is happily standing in her yellow dress with Dylan, a Kiva Fellow; Stella, another Kiva borrower; and her loan officer, Dorothy.

loans.use: To re-invest her loan for business expansion

loans.name: Balahnina

texts.ru:
L. Balahnina who is 45 years old, is married and is a mother of four children. She has secondary education. Her husband is now working in the Russian Federation and her children go to school. L. started selling fish about four years ago. When she heard about MicroInvest she decided to apply for a loan to increase her inventory sales. After receiving her loan, she acquired additional inventory, expanded her vendor space and also got new customers. Right now her assets have doubled. She plans to start selling wholesale in the future and export goods into other cities.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Балахнина Лиля –45лет. Замужем, мать четверых детей, образование среднее. Муж находится в РФ на заработках а дети учатся в школе. Начала заниматься торговлей рыбами 4 года назад. Узнав о программе МЗФ «Микроинвест» она решила получить займ и увеличить товарооборот. После получения займа она увеличила товар, расширила место, приобрела много новых клиентов. Сейчас её активы увеличились в два раза. В будущем планирует перейти на оптовую продажу и поставлять товар в другие города.

loans.use: To start selling wholesale

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred A. is a 20-year-old entrepreneur who lives in Kisumu, Kenya, with her husband and two children. Mildred set up a fruit and vegetable stall near her home in 2007. Her hard work, determination and excellent people skills have led to her success. She manages her stall during the day and sells second-hand clothes to her well-established client base in the evenings. Her profits pay the household daily expenses. She plans to use the funds from her loan of US $500 to purchase more vegetables and also to supplement her current business by selling cereals.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase stock of vegetables & cereals

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita G. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives with her mother-in-law, her husband and a daughter. Her daughter is in primary school. Her husband's name is Radesh G. and he opened his computer institute 6 years ago, where he teaches basic computer and graphic design courses. He has four computers at his institute, but that is not enough to meet the demands of the students. He wants to buy another computer, but due to lack of funds he cannot afford it. So, his wife is requesting her fourth loan to buy another computer to help her husband. This will also help to provide a better income for her family, and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy another computer

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina A. is an energetic 32-year-old mother of a 9-year-old son. Her day is segmented into 3 different selling arrangements. In the morning, she sells cooked plain rice. In the afternoon, she sells oranges. Finally, her long days end, when she sells ice water in the evening.

Faustina wants to use this loan to expand the number of products she can sell. She dreams of having her own shop one day. Now she sells the products by "hawking" them (walking around with the product on her head and selling to passersby).

Faustina's son wants to be a doctor someday, and she is hoping this loan helps her save to fund his education.

Faustina is a member of the trust group Nyame Ho Wo (God Is There). The trust group works on the principle of peer pressure, where each member of the group encourages other members to repay their share of the group loan.

Faustina is pictured shaving the peel off some of her oranges. To her left is Dorothy, her loan officer at Sinapi Aba Trust.

loans.use: To buy more inventory and expand the number of products she can sell

loans.name: Bahodurova

texts.ru:
R. Bahodurova who is 29 years old, is married and is a mother of two sons. She has a college education. After marriage she began selling women's clothing because all of the responsibilities of a family caretaker were on her shoulders after her husband went to Russian Federation to find work. She was studying in a university with hopes of getting a good education and finding a decent job in her field. But the circumstances were not in her favor of realizing her dream. She has been applying for a loan at MicroInvest since 2005 with a $100 in assets. In the future she plans to expand and increase the assortment of goods to include children's clothing.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Баходурова Рано – 29 лет. Замужем, мать двоих сынов. Образование высшее. После замужества начала заниматься продажей женскими одеждами потому как все заботы о семье легли на ее плечи после поездки мужа в РФ на заработки. Она училась в Вузе с надеждой получить хорошее образование и найти достойную работу в своей сфере. Но обстоятельства не позволили ей осуществить свою мечту. Начала кредитоваться в МЗФ Микроинвест с 2005-го года с активами на 100 долларов. А в будущем планирует расширится и добавить в свой ассортимент детскую одежду.

loans.use: Increase assortment

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40755

loans.name: Sarswati

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarswati R. lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, a son and a daughter. Her son is studying for a BBS (Bachelor in Business Studies) and her daughter is in grade 12.

Mrs. R. and her husband, Mr. Samundra Man Rangit, opened their small hotel 8 years ago. Their children help them at their hotel. They also sell Newari foods as well as dal, and bhat (Nepali food) in their shop. The local demand for Newari foods is increasing rapidly because they are tasty, and in order to meet this demand, Mrs. R. is asking for her fourth loan. She will use it to buy food, material, and furniture for their hotel. The economic conditions of their family are not that good, so she wants to invest in the hotel to increase their income and upgrade the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy food, material, and furniture

loans.name: Babita

texts.en:
Mrs. Babita S. lives in Dhalko, Kathmandu. Most of the people in this region are engaged in business like grocery shops, utensil shops, etc. Mrs. S. lives with her husband and one son who is at primary school.

Mrs. S. and her husband Mr. Rakesh S. opened their grocery shop five years ago. They sell different types of grocery items in their shop like rice, maize, noodles, biscuits, and others items. Now they are facing financial problems because competition is very high, and in order to stay in business they need to add different varieties of goods to their shop. However, due to lack of funds they cannot do this, so Mrs. S. is requesting her first loan to buy different varieties of grocery goods for their shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her shop

loans.name: Rachana

texts.en:
Mrs. Rachana G. lives in Dhalko, Kathmandu. Most of the people in this region are engaged in business. Mrs. G. lives with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 5 and her younger son is in primary school. 
Her husband's name is Niroj G., and together they opened their grocery shop 7 years ago. They sell different types of grocery items in their shop, but due to lack of money they cannot purchase grocery goods for their shop. To expand their business, Mrs. G. is requesting her first loan to buy grocery items. Their only source of income is from the shop's sales, so both of them work very hard to make their business a success.

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a 25-year-old mother of two children. Eunice and her husband live in the Nyalenda slums in Kisumu, Kenya. She began her tailoring business in the year 2006. She has been able to build a successful business due to her hard work and perseverance. She specializes in both men's and women's dresses. The central location of her shop and her many years of doing good business within the community have earned her a good reputation and a wide customer base. She is proud of her accomplishments and proud that she is now able to contribute to paying the household expenses. She requires US $600 to further expand her business. She wants to increase the variety of her clothes-making materials and purchase tailoring supplies to keep up with the growing demand.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Buy dressmaking materials

loans.name: Rina

texts.en:
Mrs. Rina S. lives with her husband and two sons in Dhalko, Kathmandu. Her older son is studying in grade 5 and her younger son is in primary school. Her husband's name is Jivan S. and he works in a private office.

Mrs. S. opened a grocery shop two years ago to raise the standard of living for her family. In Nepal, the cost of education is very high comparative to people's incomes. In order to provide an education for her children, Mrs. S. opened a grocery shop. However, due to lack of funds she can’t buy goods for her shop, so she is asking for her first loan to buy goods like rice, dal, noodles, and other items.

She needs to spend her income on providing a better education for her children and wishes to help her husband to upgrade the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds, herbicide, fertilizer and other supplies for sowing his crop

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a 29-year-old owner of a growing food preparation business. She prepares kenkey, banku, and rice balls. Kenkey and banku are delicacies prepared from milled corn, and they are very common in Ghanaian dishes for most households.

She currently works with 15 assistants and provides income to all of them. The assistants help her prepare the dishes and sell them at Kumasi's Race Course Market and Bantama Street. She hopes someday she has a permanent place of her own, as the location of her operations is temporary.

Helen is a member of the trust group called God Is One. The group exerts peer pressure on members to pay their share of the loan.

Helen is in the center of the photo, happily molding kenkey.

loans.use: To expand her business operation

loans.name: Pamfa

texts.en:
Mrs. Pamfa N. lives in Bhatkepati, Lalitpur. Bhatkepati is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. N. lives with her husband, four sons, four daughters-in-law and five grandchildren. All of her grand children are studying at school.

Mrs. N. and all other family members work on their farm. Farming is their traditional work, and they sell their vegetables at the local market every day in the morning and evening. They are totally dependent on their agricultural work because they don’t have other work. Mrs. N. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for their work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Ruhsatoi

texts.ru:
Ruhsatoi B. is 30 years old, married and mother of two children. She has a professional high school degree. For the last 5 years Ruhsatoi has been selling clothes. At first she was selling children's shoes, but after a loan from Microinvest she expanded her inventory to include men's trousers and jeans. Since her first loan Ruhsatoi has proven herself as a disciplined and punctual person. She is planning to use this loan to purchase another stall at the central market.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Бобочонова Рухсатой – 30 лет. Замужем , мать двоих детей. Образование средне специальное. Занималась торговлей детской обувью, а постепенно после получения займа в Микроинвест добавила в свой ассортимент товара и мужские брюки. Имеет опыт в этой сфере более 5 лет. За период кредитования показала себя дисциплинированной и пунктуальной личностью. В будущем планирует приобрести еще одну точку в центральном рынке.

loans.use: to open another market stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy supplies and seeds, rent machinery and pay for labor to grow a mango crop for export.

loans.name: Sushila

texts.en:
Mrs. Sushila B. lives with her husband and one son, who is one year old. Her husband's name is Rusatam B.. Both Mr. and Mrs. B. have been doing tailoring work, which they learned from their forefathers. They make school uniforms for both boys and girls. They prefer to make popular ladies' dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi, and others. Now she is seeking a loan to buy raw material like cotton cloth for the tailoring work.
